Name: VPNFilter
Description: VPNFilter is a multi-stage, modular platform with versatile capabilities to support both intelligence-collection and destructive cyber attack operations. VPNFilter modules such as its packet sniffer ('ps') can collect traffic that passes through an infected device, allowing the theft of website credentials and monitoring of Modbus SCADA protocols.   VPNFilter was assessed to be replaced by Sandworm Team with Cyclops Blink starting in 2019.

techniques_used.Use: Disk Wipe: Disk Content Wipe

techniques_used.Name: Adversary-in-the-Middle
techniques_used.Use: The VPNFilter's ssler module configures the device's iptables to redirect all traffic destined for port 80 to its local service listening on port 8888. Any outgoing web requests on port 80 are now intercepted by ssler and can be inspected by the ps module and manipulated before being sent to the legitimate HTTP service. [1] [2]

techniques_used.Name: Network Sniffing
techniques_used.Use: The VPNFilter packet sniffer looks for basic authentication as well as monitors ICS traffic, and is specific to the TP-LINK R600-VPN. The malware uses a raw socket to look for connections to a pre-specified IP address, only looking at TCP packets that are 150 bytes or larger. Packets that are not on port 502, are scanned for BasicAuth, and that information is logged. This may have allowed credential harvesting from communications between devices accessing a modbus-enabled HMI. [1] [2]

groups_that_use_this_software.Name: Sandworm Team
groups_that_use_this_software.References: VPNFilter is associated with Sandworm Team operations based on reporting on VPNFilter replacement software, Cyclops Blink.[3]

techniques_used.Name: Query Registry
techniques_used.Use: Zebrocy executes the reg query command to obtain information in the Registry.[8]
Scheduled Task/Job: Scheduled Task

techniques_used.Name: Screen Capture
techniques_used.Use: A variant of Zebrocy captures screenshots of the victim’s machine in JPEG and BMP format.[2][7][3][8][6][4]

techniques_used.Name: System Information Discovery
techniques_used.Use: Zebrocy collects the OS version, computer name and serial number for the storage volume C:. Zebrocy also runs the systeminfo command to gather system information. [1][2][7][3][8][6][4]

techniques_used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques_used.Use: Zebrocy runs the ipconfig /all command.[8]

techniques_used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
techniques_used.Use: Zebrocy uses netstat -aon to gather network connection information.[8]

techniques_used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
techniques_used.Use: Zebrocy gets the username from the system.[7][4]

techniques_used.Name: System Time Discovery
techniques_used.Use: Zebrocy gathers the current time zone and date information from the system.[7][4]

techniques_used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
techniques_used.Use: One variant of Zebrocy uses WMI queries to gather information.[3]

Name: Zen
Description: Zen is Android malware that was first seen in 2013.

techniques_used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

techniques_used.Use: Zen can simulate user clicks on ads and system prompts to create new Google accounts.[1]

techniques_used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
techniques_used.Use: Zen base64 encodes one of the strings it searches for.[1]
Process Injection: Ptrace System Calls

Name: ZergHelper
Description: ZergHelper is iOS riskware that was unique due to its apparent evasion of Apple's App Store review process. No malicious functionality was identified in the app, but it presents security risks.

techniques_used.Name: Download New Code at Runtime

Name: Zeroaccess

techniques_used.Name: Rootkit

Name: ZeroCleare
Description: ZeroCleare is a wiper malware that has been used in conjunction with the RawDisk driver since at least 2019 by suspected Iran-nexus threat actors including activity targeting the energy and industrial sectors in the Middle East and political targets in Albania.

techniques_used.Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
techniques_used.Use: ZeroCleare can receive command line arguments from an operator to corrupt the file system using the RawDisk driver.[3]
PowerShell
Disk Wipe: Disk Structure Wipe

techniques_used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
techniques_used.Use: ZeroCleare has used a vulnerable signed VBoxDrv driver to bypass Microsoft Driver Signature Enforcement (DSE) protections and subsequently load the unsigned RawDisk driver.[4]
Indicator Removal: File Deletion

techniques_used.Name: Native API
techniques_used.Use: ZeroCleare can call the GetSystemDirectoryW API to locate the system directory.[3]
Subvert Trust Controls: Code Signing

techniques_used.Name: System Information Discovery
techniques_used.Use: ZeroCleare can use the IOCTL_DISK_GET_DRIVE_GEOMETRY_EX, IOCTL_DISK_GET_DRIVE_GEOMETRY, and IOCTL_DISK_GET_LENGTH_INFO system calls to compute disk size.[3]

groups_that_use_this_software.Name: OilRig

groups_that_use_this_software.Name: HEXANE
groups_that_use_this_software.References: HEXANE probed victim infrastructure in support of HomeLand Justice.[1]

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda is a Trojan designed to steal banking information and other sensitive credentials for exfiltration. Zeus Panda’s original source code was leaked in 2011, allowing threat actors to use its source code as a basis for new malware variants. It is mainly used to target Windows operating systems ranging from Windows XP through Windows 10.

techniques_used.Use: Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder

PowerShell
Windows Command Shell

Obfuscated Files or Information: Encrypted/Encoded File

Name: ZIPLINE
